thread.title_full: Campaign Ad Watch: Anti-pot group urges voters to say no to ResponsibleOhio plan | The Columbus Dispatch

title: Campaign Ad Watch: Anti-pot group urges voters to say no to ResponsibleOhio plan
text:
Ad : “Bad Deal,” a 30-second commercial 

Producer : Ohioans Against Marijuana Monopolies 

Where it can be seen : Broadcast television in limited areas and cable. 

Video : Full screen graphic shows a quote from The Dispatch, “Marijuana Amendment is ‘BAD DEAL FOR OHIOANS’.” 

The scene shifts to men in suits at a table shuffling huge stacks of cash, followed by images of an indoor marijuana growing site and marijuana-infused candies. 

A graphic shows groups opposing Issue 3, including the Fraternal Order of Police of Ohio, Ohio State Medical Association, Ohio Nurses Association, Ohio School Boards Association, and Ohio newspapers. 

Script : An announcer speaks: “Issue 3, the marijuana amendment, is a ‘bad deal’ 

It would change Ohio’s Constitution and grant a few wealthy investors a marijuana monopoly. 

They get exclusive ownership of marijuana sites to make millions. 

Issue 3 allows marijuana lollipops, gummy bears and candy, posing a threat to our kids. 

Join Ohio’s police, doctors, nurses, educators and leading newspapers in voting NO. 

NO on the monopoly. NO on marijuana candy. NO on Issue 3.” 

Analysis : This ad — the first and perhaps only one to be aired by Issue 3 opponents — relieves heavily on strong images and repeating “No” verbally and in print to hammer home that marijuana legalization is bad for Ohioans. 

The strongest points are the monopoly issue, driven home by a group of men seated around a table shuffling huge stacks of money, and the potential lure for children of pot-laced lollipops, gummy bears and other candies. The accompanying images touch emotions: anger about people getting rich at the expense of others, and fear of children falling prey to drugs disguised as candy. 

But do those images reflect reality? 

Issue 3 would grant a monopoly for commercial growing and wholesale sale of marijuana for at least four years, and perhaps beyond, for 10 investment groups which own pre-selected sites around the state. After that, a state commission could add to the number of growers, but only if the market demand exceeded the ability of the 10 growers to provide the product. 

Would growers get rich? The state Office of Budget and Management estimated marijuana sales could hit $2 billion a year, so somebody is going to make money. The investors are gambling that their multi-million-dollar investments will pay off handsomely. 

Supporters of Issue 3 argue that rigorous packaging standards will be in place for edibles so they are clearly marked to avoid children accidentally ingesting them. Nevertheless, accidental poisonings of children are up in Colorado, where recreational and medical marijuana are legal. An individually wrapped gummy bear or lollipop still looks like candy to a toddler.
